data.title: [OpenGL] Texture unload does not free up memory
data.body:
Following up our issue with the content unload not called automatically, we still have huge memory leak with non-managed content.
I noticed that the current fix for ContentManager still does not call unload, and rendertarget's destructor called, but the real thing is:
The following line in Texture.cs:
GL.DeleteTextures(1, ref glTexture);
Does not free a single byte of memory.

Any ideas why?

data.title: Touch behavior not consistent with Windows Phone 7
data.body:
I did some testing of pull 852 on Windows 8 against WP7 I noticed the differences:
1. On WP7, a Pinch gesture is generated with every moved after the Pinch is detected, MonoGame currently does not.
2. MonoGame does not generate a DragComplete gesture when a drag gesture starts before the Flick is detected.
3. On WP7, the DragComplete gesture and Release TouchLocation always occur in the same Update
4. On WP7, the PinchComplete gesture and Release TouchLocations always occur in the same Update
5. On WP7 when Vertical Drag, Horizontal Drag and Free Drag are enabled, the gesture recognition favors vertical and horizontal over free drag, only generating FreeDrag on irregular movements. On MonoGame it only returns FreeDrag in this scenario.

I generated a file each for WP7 and MonoGame that shows the gestures and touchLocations returned per Update for each gesture type.

Here is a link: https://gist.github.com/3873555

data.title: VerticalDrag not working [Fix Included]
data.body:
I posted this right after the issue [here](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/852) was closed. ill include the bug and fix here to make sure it gets seen. The fix is basic and is included in the 'EDIT' comment 

---

Working in the latest develop3d branch I noticed IsGestureAvailable is always returning true with FreeDrag even though VerticalDrag is the only enabled Gesture.

I updated the return value of IsGestureAvailable to read :

return GestureList.Any(g => EnabledGestures.HasFlag(g.GestureType));

This resolves the issue with FreeDrag showing up, but it better presents the underlying issue that VerticalDrag is never being set.

it appears that in TouchPanel.cs in the ProcessDrag method if(dragH) is being tested as it takes precedence, but the case for !dragH is never being handled. So if(dragH) needs to be followed up with an else if(dragV)

hopefully this is the most appropriate place to bring this to your attention.

EDIT:

swapping the if statement to if(dragH || dragV) resolves both issues

We are currently working on switching levels in our game. We use a contentmanager for the gamescreen, which should be unloaded when a new level is loaded. After several level changes, we receive a low memory crash.

data.title: Orientation ignored when hooked to 2nd monitor
data.body:
I actually don't know if this is intended behavior or not, but thought I'd bring it up for discussion.

I am developing on a Samsung Tablet.  If the Samsung tablet is undocked, or if it's docked but not outputting video to a 2nd monitor then my game which sets 

 graphics.SupportedOrientations = DisplayOrientation.Portrait;

appears in portrait mode just fine.

If however I run the game when the tablet is docked and outputting video to a 2nd monitor, the game runs in landscape mode - as if it ignores the portrait command.  I understand this may be because the second monitor is in landscape and maybe W8 doesn't support one device being in portrait while one is in landscape.   Is this the case?  Does this mean that all games we create which run in portrait mode must also run in landscape?

data.title: SamplerStates aren't properly applied when active texture changes
data.body:
I haven't gotten to the bottom of this one yet, but basically sampler states aren't being applied properly when the active texture has changed.

I use SampleState.PointClamp for rendering CraftStudio's low-poly, pixelated models.

When I change the texture bound to my "textureSampler" parameter (which should be called Texture, but that is another story ;) #641), and then apply my effect, the sampler state isn't properly applied and I get the default interpolation filter (linear & wrap I think) instead of what I requested (point & clamp).

This means that the very first model to be rendered in my scene (with texture 1) has proper texture sampling, and then all subsequent models (with textures 2, 3, 4 ...) are linearly interpolated.

Disabling the _dirty checks in SamplerStateCollection.SetSamplers() fixes the issue, so my guess is the dirty bit flag isn't being set when it should in some cases. I'll report back later if I find a proper fix.

(Obviously this works correctly in XNA)

data.title: MonoMacGameView has 16-bit depth size instead of 24-bit like XNA
Game.Window.ClientBounds.Width and Height do not reflect orientation until Game.Update
data.body:
This was tested on an undocked Samsung tablet (the game actually does go into portrait mode).  The resolution is 1366X768.  I reproduced this as follows:
- Set the graphics.SupportedOrientations = DisplayOrientation.Portrait in the Game's constructor
- Create class variables to record values throughout the execution of the constructor, Game.Initialize(), and Game.Update().
-  Notice that the resolution width is 1366 for all values set in the constructor and Initialize, but the value changes to 768 the first time that Update is called.

This is problematic because some games perform resolution-specific resolution in Initialize.

data.title: GameTime.IsRunningSlowly?
data.body:
I see in the Game.cs code that GameTime.IsRunningSlowly is not implemented. According to the XNA docs:

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.gametime.isrunningslowly.aspx

"Gets a value indicating that the game loop is taking longer than its TargetElapsedTime. In this case, the game loop can be considered to be running too slowly and should do something to "catch up." "

To that end, I propose on line 463:

```
            _gameTime.IsRunningSlowly = (_accumulatedElapsedTime > TargetElapsedTime);
```

This is a bit draconian, but the comment from Microsoft appears to be exactly that - draconian. 

What sayeth thee?
